RENEW leverages SC 's unique national labor atories, user facilities, and other research infrastructures to provide undergraduate and graduate training opportunities for students and academic institutions not currently well represented in the U.S. science and technology (S&T) ecosystem. The hands -on experiences gained through RENEW will open new career avenues for participants, forming a nucleus for a future pool of talented young scientists, engineers, and technicians with the critical skills and expertise needed for the full breadth of SC research activities. Principal Investigators (PIs) , key personnel, and students and postdocs of RENEW 2 awards will be invited to participate in Isotope R&D and Production ( DOE Isotope Program or DOE IP) researcher meetings and/or SC -wide professional development and collaborator events. As a part of the RENEW initiative, DOE IP hereby announces its interest in receiving applications from Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) seeking to participate in a training, research, and development program related to the mission space of DOE IP. Successful applications will incorporate isotope science and technology relevant coursework for undergraduate and/or graduate students, as well as research and/or isotope production experiences at DOE IP supported isotope production sites to expose students to potential career paths and foster the development and training of the next generation of workforce in isotope related science. Awards are envisioned to be led by an MSI and include a minimum of one DOE IP isotope production si te as a subaward recipient , acting as a resource in training, research, and development efforts. Successful applicants will describe activities including student recruitment, development of collaborative networks in support of trainee experiences, organiza tion of virtual and/or in- person workshops and meetings for trainees and mentors, establishing peer support groups for students, training for mentors, and trainee career advancement assistance. SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION Program Objective The mission of the DOE IP is to: Produce and/or distribute radioactive and stable isotopes that are in short supply. Maintain the infrastructure required to produce and supply isotope products and related services. Conduct R&D on new and improved isotope production and processing technologies that can make isotopes available for essential research and applications. Decrease U.S. dependency on foreign supply of critical isotopes. Produced isotopes are obtained by di rect production or recovery from by- products and surplus government -owned materials. The DOE IP also provides specialized services related to the distribution of isotopes. The DOE IP supports production and processing facilities at the Low - Energy Accelerat or Facility (LEAF) at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Brookhaven Linear Isotope Producer (BLIP) facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), the Isotope Production Facility (IPF) at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), the High Flux Isotope Reactor (HFIR) and stable enrichment capabilities at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), the Advanced Test Reactor (ATR) at Idaho National Laboratory (INL), and processing facilities at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL). In addition, the Progra m coordinates and supports isotope production at a suite of academic accelerator and reactor facilities throughout the Nation, known as the University Isotope Network (UIN), to promote a reliable domestic supply of essential isotopes (University of Washington, University of Missouri, University of Alabama- Birmingham, and University of Wisconsin- Madison). The ability of DOE IP to fulfill this mission relies on the availability of a highly trained, diverse community of investigators, researchers, engineers, technicians, students, and other staff that provides great benefit to the nation by broadly contributi ng to and advancing fields such as 3 medicine, national security, domestic and global industry, and basic scientific research. The nation would benefit from widening the pool of potential talent to develop the next generation of scientists, engineers, and te chnicians involved in isotope production and processing. The SC RENEW effort seeks to support individuals and institutions historically underrepresented in the SC research portfolio. Critical to this initiative are institutional efforts for recruiting dive rse participation and creating and maintaining positive, inclusive, and professional research and learning environments, including but not limiting to providing mentoring and professional development resources to students and early career researchers and f ostering a sense of belonging among all research personnel. Ultimately, the goal of this FOA is to begin to invest in students as early as possible in their scientific training to ensure that the broadest pool of potential isotope scientists is domestically available, thereby helping to maintain the U.S. position at the forefront of the field with a technically sophisticated and innovative program. Evaluation The SC RENEW initiative builds foundations for research and training at historically underre presented institutions in the SC research portfolio through new partnership models and through supporting research and training applications that include project elements aimed at directly addressing barriers to participation. An integral part of this effort, is the evaluation of successful approaches, including the impact of the RENEW initiative on recruiting and retaining individuals from diverse backgrounds. Evaluation related to the impacts of RENEW on project participants will be conducted through a ce ntralized SC effort, administered by the Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education (ORISE) on behalf of SC. Recipient institutions and their subrecipients at every tier will be requested to provide information to ORISE about the content of training opportunities/curricula provided to students and postdocs supported by this award and the career paths taken by these participants. Information will be requested no more frequently than annually and may be requested for no more than ten years after the end of any award 's period of performance. Recipient institutions and their subrecipients should therefore plan to maintain communication with student and postdoc participants to respond to ORISE requests. DOE IP RENEW Expectations All applications must be subm itted by an MSI on behalf of a team that includes at least one existing DOE IP production site (either UIN members or national laboratory sites). Additional MSIs, other academic institutions, and/or DOE/NNSA National Laboratories may also be added to form larger teams. Any institution that 4 either receives funding through a Department of Education MSI funding program (coded 6 on the matrix) or that is eligible to receive such funding (coded 5 on the matrix) will be considered an MSI for this FOA The DOE IP RENEW initia tive is envisioned to combine coursework available at educationally appropriate levels specifically focusing on aspects of physics, chemistry, and materials science & engineering as well as other relevant Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields that underpin isotope production with research experience to provide an important foundation on which participants can build. Pairing the above with summer opportunities for participants to travel to DOE IP production sites, like the highly specialized facilities and resources at the DOE/NNSA National Laboratories, exposes students to the career opportunities inherent to isotope science. Responsive applications to this FOA should include research components. All research activities should expl ore innovative approaches to isotope production and processing involving, but not limited to any of the following related research competencies: advanced manufacturing, artificial intelligence and machine learning, and robotics. Applications that focus on isotope applications or end usage are nonresponsive to this FOA. The DOE IP expects that an inclusive environment be fostered at all sites where work is funded. Therefore, if an undergraduate or graduate student is unable to conduct off -campus research, alternative plans should be developed to accommodate this and ensure that an equal quality experience is available. Undergraduate Students It is anticipated that undergraduate students would be afforded the opportunity to engage with faculty con ducting research at their home institutions related to innovative and transformative approaches to isotope production and processing as well as participate in a selection of course work at an appropriate level. Material and supply costs related to undergra duate student research would be appropriate costs for the DOE IP RENEW initiative. During the summer months, undergraduate students would have the opportunity (at the expense of the DOE IP RENEW initiative) to travel for two weeks with their peers in the DOE IP RENEW initiative to a selection of DOE IP production sites for an off -campus, workshop- like learning experience. The experience could include lectures, research presentations, and tours designed to expose them to the breadth of work conducted at the sites and build a sense of community. Alternatively, longer periods could be proposed to include the conduct of on- site research at the collaborating facilities. Graduate Students It is likewise anticipated that participating graduate students be afforde d access to isotope science -related coursework and the student, and their advisor develop a plan to collaborate with DOE IP production sites, off -site from their home institution, in their dissertation work. It is imagined that the students (at the expense of the initiative) would spend three or more weeks, for each of two summers, conducting hands -on related work under the guidance of DOE IP production site collaborators. They would also attend/give research presentations and take tours 5 designed to expose them to various aspects of the isotope work conducted at that site. Students should be encouraged to consider visiting more than one site to begin to appreciate the diversity and breadth of science conducted by the DOE IP. Additionally, the summer stipend and associated indirect costs of each graduate student would be paid by the DOE IP RENEW initiative. RENEW Faculty and Mentors: Applications with clear mentoring plans will be favored. Applications should clearly articulate benefits to the participant stu dents, including skills acquired, networking opportunities, and breadth of exposure to isotope processing and production. In order to recognize and formalize the role of those involved in mentoring, the proposed inclusion of partial support for summer salary (typically half a month) for faculty and/or partial salary support for postdocs , technical, academic, and/or scientific staff (typically 30%) will be considered; and if appropriate, should be included in the mentoring plan and named as co- PIs.
